intro: Abies fabri subsp. fordei, commonly known as the Forde's fir, is a rare and endemic subspecies native to the mountainous regions of northern China. It is a coniferous evergreen tree characterized by its needle-like leaves and cone-bearing structure typical of the fir genus. The foliage is typically dark green and densely packed, providing a dense canopy. It thrives in cool, moist environments with well-drained soil, often found in high-altitude forests. Due to its limited distribution and habitat specificity, it is considered a species of conservation concern.

The plant is often associated with mixed evergreen and deciduous forests in its native habitat. Its distribution is limited to specific elevational ranges, usually between 1,500 and 3,000 meters above sea level.
distribution_introduced_art_desc: Abies fabri subsp. fordei was mainly introduced to ornamental horticulture due to its attractive conical shape and slow growth rate.
